notes_1: "The AU mediated a round of peace talks between the SPLM-North and the Sudanese government on a political solution to the conflict from 23 to 27 April 2013, but these talks ended without agreement."

"The SSDM/A led by Olony accepted a ceasefire and an amnesty by the government following mediation by the Shilluk reth (King) in June 2013. Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013."
"Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013."

agreement name: Integration of rebel leaders into national army
notes_1: "Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Major General Johnson Olony into the government forces. The SSDM/A remained loyal to the government until early 2015, when they defected to the SPLM/A-IO."

"The armed conflict between Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army - In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) and the Government of South Sudan started in mid-December 2013, when two different factions within the Presidential guard clashed in Juba. One faction was loyal to President Salva Kiir, while the other faction was loyal to the former vice-president Riek Machar. Machar had been ousted from the government in July 2013. In mid-December, President Kiir accused Riek Machar of conducting a coup d’état, but this accusation later proved to be unsubstantiated. The accusation is widely seen as a pretext for crack down on Machar and pushing all Nuer troops out of Juba, after which Nuer civilians were targeted. Armed clashes between the conflict parties quickly spread to other areas, in particular to Bor, Malakal, and Bentiu. In response to the armed conflict, Salva Kiir also detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals, accusing them of conspiring with Riek Machar to overthrow the government. The political prisoners were all senior SPLM/A party members who had begun to openly criticize the president in 2013. This group has commonly been referred to as the “former detainees” after the first seven were released in January 2013 and the remaining four were released in in May 2014. As soon as the war broke out, Uganda intervened in the civil war in support of the South Sudanese government, while Sudan supported the SPLM/A-IO with weapons and ammunition. A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU."

A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU."

"The armed conflict between Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army - In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) and the Government of South Sudan started in mid-December 2013, when two different factions within the Presidential guard clashed in Juba. One faction was loyal to President Salva Kiir, while the other faction was loyal to the former vice-president Riek Machar. Machar had been ousted from the government in July 2013. In mid-December, President Kiir accused Riek Machar of conducting a coup d’état, but this accusation later proved to be unsubstantiated. The accusation is widely seen as a pretext for crack down on Machar and pushing all Nuer troops out of Juba, after which Nuer civilians were targeted. Armed clashes between the conflict parties quickly spread to other areas, in particular to Bor, Malakal, and Bentiu. In response to the armed conflict, Salva Kiir also detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals, accusing them of conspiring with Riek Machar to overthrow the government. The political prisoners were all senior SPLM/A party members who had begun to openly criticize the president in 2013. This group has commonly been referred to as the “former detainees” after the first seven were released in January 2013 and the remaining four were released in in May 2014. As soon as the war broke out, Uganda intervened in the civil war in support of the South Sudanese government, while Sudan supported the SPLM/A-IO with weapons and ammunition. A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU."

"On 26 December, a second IGAD delegation – led by the President of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, and the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Dessalegn – visited Juba for peace talks with the President of South Sudan, members of the Cabinet, and the detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals. The IGAD delegation also tried to further probe into the root causes of the conflict and discuss how best to address it. IGAD held an extraordinary summit in Nairobi on 27 December 2013, where three special envoys – Ambassador Seyoum Mesfin of Ethiopia, General Lazaro Sumbeiywo of Kenya, and General Mohamed Ahmed Mustapha al-Dabi of the Sudan – were appointed to support a resolution of the crisis."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "The peace process between the government and the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction was brought to Addis Ababa in January 2014. This mediation effort was conducted by the South Sudanese Church Leaders Mediation Initiative (CLMI). Hizkias Assefa, an Ethiopian professor and mediator, acted as the chief mediator during this peace process. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 January 2014."

"At the start of a round of negotiations on 25 February 2014, the Sudanese government accepted the draft framework agreement put forward by AUHIP to cease hostilities and deliver humanitarian aid to civilians in Sudan’s ‘Two Areas’ of Blue Nile and South Kordofan, but negotiations between the SPLM/A-N and the government were suspended on 2 March 2014 because the conflict parties disagreed on how the resolve the conflict."
"The AU mediated another round of negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan on 22 April 2014, but this round of negotiations also failed."

"On 27 January 2014, President al-Bashir announced the creation of a national dialogue to address Sudan’s political instability. On 31 January 2014, Sudan and Chad agreed to send special envoys to meet and encourage Darfur rebel groups that refused to sign a peace agreement with the Sudanese government, to engage in peace talks.  Several meetings were held throughout 2014 aimed at initiating a formal peace process between the Sudanese government and the SRF. The joint AU-UN Special Envoy, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, met with the SRF leadership in Kampala on 12 February 2014 to discuss the possibility of formal negotiations. To prepare for the national dialogue, the leaders of the SRF and the Umma Party, a Sudanese opposition party, decided to form an alliance at a meeting in Paris on 8 August 2014. They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue."

They signed the Paris Declaration, calling for national dialogue."

agreement name: The Paris Declaration
notes_1: The UN and AU supported a meeting in Paris between the Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF) and the National Umma Party (NUP), which culminated in the Paris Declaration.

agreement name: The Paris Declaration
notes_1: The UN and AU supported a meeting in Paris between the Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF) and the National Umma Party (NUP), which culminated in the Paris Declaration.

"On 1 September 2014, leaders of the SRF met with the chairman of the AU High Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), Thabo Mbeki, in Addis Ababa to discuss the format of future negotiations. On the basis of this discussion, the African Union’s Peace and Security Council issued Communique 456 on 15 September 2014, which stipulated that government’s talks with the Darfuris and SPLM-North should be conducted in a synchronized manner, referred to as the “one process, two tracks” approach. This effectively focused the negotiations on reaching a ceasefire in both Darfur and the two areas, while simultaneously implementing the national dialogue that al-Bashir had announced in January 2014. The alliance between the SRF and the Umma Party forged in Paris in August was reiterated and extended to include other traditional political party leaders and civil society representatives on 3 December 2014, with the signing of the Sudan Call."

"A round of AUHIP-mediated negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government started in Addis Abba on 12 November 2014. This round of negotiations consisted of two track. The SLM/A-MM and the JEM negotiated with the government on a ceasefire in Darfur (the SLM/A-AW boycotted this round of talks with the government), while the SPLM/A-North negotiated on a ceasefire in the two areas. This round of negotiations ended with the AU mediation team announcing on 9 December 2014 that the government delegation and the SPLM-North failed to agree on a ceasefire. The reason for this deadlock was that the SPLM/A-North had insisted on a comprehensive solution for Sudan entirely, while Khartoum insisted on a cessation of hostilities for the Blue Nile and South Kordofan only. What is more, the Sudanese government had already initiated what it referred to as a deceive summer campaign in South Kordofan on 1 December 2014."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "IGAD began to mediate direct negotiations between the conflict parties in early 2014. Seyoum Mesfin, who had been the Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1991 until September 2010, was the chief mediator of the peace process. A first round of negotiations took place in Addis Ababa between 2 and 23 January 2014. These negotiations mainly focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire, as well as on the release of some political prisoners taken by the government. The mediation team led by Mesfin considered a ceasefire unlikely to hold unless underlying political grievances were addressed, but they deemed that a reduction in violence was necessary to create the space for substantial negotiations. Hence, the negotiations first focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 23 January 2014, which took effect the next day.  The ceasefire committed the conflict parties to end offensive operations, freeze their forces in place, and refrain from attacks against civilians. The ceasefire also established a monitoring and verification mechanism."

"The Sudanese Awakening Revolutionary Council (SARC) was established on 4 January 2014. The group was led by Musa Hilal, a chief of the Arab Mahamid tribe and former leader of the Janjaweed that conducted a massive counterinsurgency campaign against rebel groups in Darfur. In January 2014, Hilal defected from the Sudanese government. On 17 March 2014, President Omar al-Bashir sent a delegation to Darfur to negotiate with Musa Hilal. In late March 2014, Chad hosted peace talks between the conflict parties in the Chadian border town of Um Jaras, but this did not lead to an agreement. By late 2014, Hilal was running his own administration in North Darfur, with his troops controlling Saraf Umra town, Kutum town, Kabkabiya town, and the El Waha area. To this purpose, Hilal set up a council composed of native leaders to perform administrative and judicial functions in these areas. A tax system with various fees for vehicles travelling in their areas of control was also set up. SARC also profited from artisan gold mining in Jabal Amer."
"Russia mediated peace talks between Sudan and South Sudan in Moscow on 10 September 2015."

agreement name: Agreement for a buffer zone with join units deployed for monitoring
notes_1: "On 14 October 2015, Sudan and South Sudan convened for peace talks in Addis Abba. At this round of talks, Sudan and South Sudan agreed to establish a buffer zone with join units deployed for monitoring."

"On 7 July 2015, Secretary–General of the SPLM/A-N Yasir Arman stated that the SPLM/A-N would not continue peace negotiations from where the last round of AU-led peace talks stopped. On 3 August 2015, President Omar al-Bashir met with AU chief mediator Thabo Mbeki to discuss peace in Blue Nile and South Kordofan states. The meeting between Mbeki and al-Bashir did not lead to a new date for the resumption of negotiations on the two areas. The Government of Sudan and the SPLM-North engaged in direct negotiations mediated by the AU between 19 and 23 November 2015. This round of negotiations focused on security arrangements."

"In December 2015, the Sudanese government and SPLM/A-North expressed to the AUHIP their willingness to sign a comprehensive agreement. An informal round of peace talks was subsequently held in Addis Ababa from 16 to 18 December 2015. However, this round of talks did not lead to an agreement, as the parties disagreed about whether the SPLM/A-North should be allowed to keep its troops. The conflict parties and the mediation team agreed to resume discussions in January 2016."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "On 12 January 2015, the conflict parties signed another ceasefire in the IGAD-led mediation process, as well committed themselves to accelerate efforts to reach an agreement based on the formation of a transitional government."

agreement name: Arusha Agreement
notes_1: "Negotiations in Arusha  between 9 to 19 January 2015 brought together President Salva Kiir representing the SPLM/A-In Government, Rick Riek Machar representing the SPLM/A-In Opposition, and Deng Alor Kuol representing the SPLM/A-Former Detainees. John Samuel Malecela, the Vice Chairman of Tanzania’s ruling party the Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), and Abdulrahman Kinana, the CCM General-Secretary, acted as the chief mediators at this round of negotiations in Arusha. The negotiations led to the signing of the Agreement on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (Arusha Agreement) on 21 January 2015."

"The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO met in Addis Ababa on 27 and 28 January 2015 for two days of  IGAD-mediated negotiations prior to the IGAD Head of States Summit on 29 January.  These negotiations focused on power-sharing. The IGAD mediation team proposed to make Riek Machar vice-president again, but keeping James Wani Igga as a second vice-president. Politicians from Equatoria expressed opposition to this proposal, asserting that Igga should hold a more senior position to Riek Machar in a future power-sharing agreement."

"Another round of IGAD-led negotiations in Addis Abba started on 23 February 2015. Prior to the start of this round of negotiations, both the AU and IGAD threatened sanctions against South Sudan if a comprehensive power sharing deal is not reached by 5 March. One major disagreement during the negotiations was that the SPLM/A-IO demanded the creation of two separate armies in the country during the transitional period, with the SPLM/A-IO fighters being officially recognized as a separate army. The negotiations broke down on 6 March 2015."

The negotiations broke down on 6 March 2015."

"On 27 June 2015, President Salva Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Riek Machar conducted a consultative meeting in Nairobi under the auspices of President Kenyatta of Kenya to review elements of the proposed peace agreement."

"The IGAD mediation effort resumed in June, but was officially reconfigured as “IGAD Plus” in June 2015, expanding the mediation team to also include representatives from five African Union member states, the UN, the Troika (US, UK, and Norway), the EU, and China. A new round of negotiations was initiated in Addis Ababa on 9 June 2015. This round of negotiations ended on 25 June, with agreement that the IGAD mediation would circulate a “compromise agreement” in July, which was the product of negotiations and consultations since January 2014."

"At a new round of negotiations that had started with a summit in Addis Ababa on 27 July chaired by President Barack Obama, it was decided that the conflict parties would have until 17 August 2015 to sign a final peace agreement. Several amendments were subsequently negotiated on the basis of the draft agreement. For instance, the conflict parties agreed that the deadline for the complete integration of the SPLM/A-IO forces into the national army would be within 30 months of signing of the agreement, instead of the 18 months proposed by the mediators."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the holding of a summit.

notes_1: "At a new round of negotiations that had started with a summit in Addis Ababa on 27 July chaired by President Barack Obama, it was decided that the conflict parties would have until 17 August 2015 to sign a final peace agreement. Several amendments were subsequently negotiated on the basis of the draft agreement. For instance, the conflict parties agreed that the deadline for the complete integration of the SPLM/A-IO forces into the national army would be within 30 months of signing of the agreement, instead of the 18 months proposed by the mediators."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the holding of a summit.

agreement name: Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan
notes_1: "Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Bostwana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishment of the Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC).

agreement name: Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan
notes_1: "Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Bostwana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement."

agreement name: Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement
notes_1: "Another round of IGAD-led negotiations led to the signing of the Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement on 3 November 2015. This Agreement concerns the details on the implementation of the Transitional Government of National Unity (TGONU) and the Transitional National Assembly (TNA), as well as the adoption of the transitional constitution. The agreement also specified that the SPLM/A-IO was allowed to deploy 1,410 security personel in Juba and the government 3,420 security personnel."

"On 5 April 2014, Chadian President Idris Deby met the Chairman of JEM, Jibril Ibrahim, in Paris to discuss a roadmap for official negotiations. The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016."

"The Darfur Joint Resistance Forces is a coalition comprised of the SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and the Sudan Liberation Movement for Justice (SLMJ). It was established in 2014. Taher Hajar was the leader of SLMJ until his killing during clashes in June 2014, with Ali Karbino serving as military leader for the SLMJ. The SLM/A and the SLM/A-MM maintained their membership with the SRF in spite of also joining the Darfur Joint Resistance Forces. The Darfur Joint Resistance Forces mainly operated in the northern part of Darfur.  Between 2 and 4 June 2016, US and Chadian diplomats held shuttle talks with representatives from the SLMJ and Sudanese government representatives in Chad. The shuttle talks were aimed at finding a way in which SLMJ could join the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)."

"The Darfur Joint Resistance Forces is a coalition comprised of the SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and the Sudan Liberation Movement for Justice (SLMJ). It was established in 2014. Between 2 and 4 June 2016, US and Chadian diplomats held shuttle talks with representatives from the SLMJ and Sudanese government representatives in Chad. The shuttle talks were aimed at finding a way in which SLMJ could join the Doha Document for Peace in Darfur (DDPD)."

"In November 2011, the SPLM/A-north, SLM/A, SLM/A-MM, and JEM formed a new rebel coalition: the Sudanese Revolutionary Army (SRF). The rebel groups declared to collectively fight to topple the Sudanese Government. The UCDP assigns some armed clashes to the SLM/A-MM and some to the SRF from 2011 onwards. Accordingly, any peace efforts only involving the SLM/A-MM are listed here, while peace efforts involving the SRF are listed under that dyad.  The JEM and the SLM/A-MM on the one side and the government on the other side held informal discussions, mediated by the AU, in the Ethiopian town of Debre Zeit on 23 January 2016."

"The government’s military, summer campaign in South Kordofan continued until mid-January 2015 and was extended to Blue Nile in February 2015. In addition, the Sudanese government refused to attend a preparatory meeting for the national dialogue that the AUHIP had wanted to facilitate in Addis Ababa on 29 and 30 March 2015. This effectively ended the SRF’s participation in the national dialogue. On 24 August 2015, the Sudanese government announced a two-month ceasefire with the SRF, which could be extended if progress is made in negotiations.  The ceasefire applied to both Darfur and the Blue Nile and South Kordofan. The SRF agreed to the ceasefire and also indicated it was ready resume negotiations with the government without further delay. On 14 September 2015, the SRF leadership announced that it was ready to sign a six-month cessation of hostilities agreement with the Sudanese government. The SRF further called on the government to “engage in a comprehensive dialogue.” In January 2016, the SRF leadership met with the Qatari deputy prime minister in Paris to discuss the possibility of official peace negotiations"
"In addition, informal negotiations between the SRF and the Sudanese government were held in Berlin between 22 and 24 January 2016."

"Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF took place in leadership in Addis Ababa between 19 and 21 March. Based on this round of talks, the AU mediators drew up a roadmap agreement for the conflict parties’ consideration. The Sudanese government signed the roadmap agreement on 21 March 2016, but the SRF refused to sign the roadmap. Subsequent third party efforts were aimed at making the SRF accept the roadmap."

"Another round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and the SRF took place in leadership in Addis Ababa between 19 and 21 March. Based on this round of talks, the AU mediators drew up a roadmap agreement for the conflict parties’ consideration. The Sudanese government signed the roadmap agreement on 21 March 2016, but the SRF refused to sign the roadmap. Subsequent third party efforts were aimed at making the SRF accept the roadmap."

"On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement."

"On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement."

"On 17 June 2016, Donald Booth, the US special envoy to Sudan and South Sudan, met with representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, as well as representatives from the National Umma Party, in Addis Ababa. Booth tried to persuade the JEM and the SLM/A-MM representatives to sign the roadmap agreement."

"The conflict parties started another round of AU-mediated negotiations in mid-August 2016. These negotiations were supposed to focus on implementing the roadmap agreement, but the AUHIP declared the collapse of Darfur and Two Areas Ceasefire talks on 15 August 2016, blaming the JEM and the SLM/A-MM for introducing new demands on issues that had previously been agreed and which contradicted the roadmap agreement. The mediation team therefore postponed the negotiations indefinitely."

agreement name: Roadmap Agreement
notes_1: "Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the SRF in Addis Abba in early August 2016 made some progress. On 8 August 2016, the SRF accepted and signed the roadmap agreement put forward by the AU on 21 March 2016. The roadmap stipulates a ceasefire, as well as outlined a framework for negotiations on the conflicts in Darfur and the two areas of Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile."

agreement name: Roadmap Agreement
notes_1: "Another round of negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the SRF in Addis Abba in early August 2016 made some progress. On 8 August 2016, the SRF accepted and signed the roadmap agreement put forward by the AU on 21 March 2016. The roadmap stipulates a ceasefire, as well as outlined a framework for negotiations on the conflicts in Darfur and the two areas of Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile."

conflict sub-locale: Nuba Mountains; Blue Nile; South Kordofan
notes_1: "A government attack on the SPLM/A-North in Aroum on 23 January 2016 led SPLM/A-North officials to publicly question the government’s commitment to establishing peace. In late 2016, the AUHIP called upon the SPLM/A-North to review their positions on the talks on the Two Areas. The SPLM/A-N insisted on a provision allowing humanitarian access through Asosa in Ethiopia, but the Sudanese government rejected such a provision. In March 2017, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-North (SPLM/A-N) split into two factions, resulting in several clashes. While there were many calls to engage in negotiations throughout 2017 and 2018, the conflict parties did not engage in peace talks. The split was a result of long-simmering ethnic and political–military tensions within the SPLM/A-N in Blue Nile. While the Uduk, Berta, and Burun had made up the majority of the SPLM/A’s 10th Division during war between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government between 1983 and 2005, members of the Ingessana tribe assumed increasingly more power within the rebel group from 2012 onwards. This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the non-Ingessana tribes. Tensions were temporarily put on hold due to intense fighting between the SPLM/A-N and government forces throughout 2015-2016, but following a unilateral ceasefire issued by the Sudanese government on 18 June 2016 tensions escalated. In March 2017, SPLM/A-N deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu publicly released a resignation letter. Abdelaziz al-Hilu accused Agar of not fully representing the entire SPLM/A-N movement in the peace process led by the AU, particularly with regard to the issue of self-determination of the Nuba Mountains. Al-Hilu’s letter essentially forced the members of the SPLM/A-N to choose between himself and chairman Malik Agar of the Ingessana tribe. The Nuba Mountains Liberation Council (NMLC) subsequently passed resolutions that removed Arman as the SPLM/A-N’s lead negotiator with African Union High-Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), as well as put the NMLC in power of both South Kordofan and Blue Nile. Moreover, many senior non-Ingessana leaders began to publicly voice support for al-Hilu and the NMLC. In April 2017, almost all of the non-Ingessana Blue Nile Liberation Council (BNLC) members declared their support for the NMLC decision to dismiss Arman as the SPLM/A-N AUHIP lead negotiator. Accordingly, although the deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu broke away from the rebel group led by chairman Malik Agar, the UCDP codes the SPLM/A-N led by Malik Agar (SPLM/A-N-MA) as the splinter faction because he was endorsed by the NMLC and most of the BNLC.  Preparations for official negotiations between the SPLM/A-North and the Sudanese government continued in spite of this split. SPLM/A-North representatives met with mediators from the AUHIP in Addis Ababa in late August 2017. In late September 2017, Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) special envoy for Sudan, Lesane Johannes, discussed details for the resumption of formal peace talks between the SPLM-North and the government with Sudanese Presidential adviser Ibrahim Mahmoud. However, these pre-negotiations did not lead to formal negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan were held in 2017."

However, these pre-negotiations did not lead to formal negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan were held in 2017."

conflict sub-locale: Nuba Mountains; Blue Nile; South Kordofan
notes_1: "A government attack on the SPLM/A-North in Aroum on 23 January 2016 led SPLM/A-North officials to publicly question the government’s commitment to establishing peace. In late 2016, the AUHIP called upon the SPLM/A-North to review their positions on the talks on the Two Areas. The SPLM/A-N insisted on a provision allowing humanitarian access through Asosa in Ethiopia, but the Sudanese government rejected such a provision. In March 2017, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-North (SPLM/A-N) split into two factions, resulting in several clashes. While there were many calls to engage in negotiations throughout 2017 and 2018, the conflict parties did not engage in peace talks. The split was a result of long-simmering ethnic and political–military tensions within the SPLM/A-N in Blue Nile. While the Uduk, Berta, and Burun had made up the majority of the SPLM/A’s 10th Division during war between the SPLM/A and the Sudanese government between 1983 and 2005, members of the Ingessana tribe assumed increasingly more power within the rebel group from 2012 onwards. This led to widespread dissatisfaction among the non-Ingessana tribes. Tensions were temporarily put on hold due to intense fighting between the SPLM/A-N and government forces throughout 2015-2016, but following a unilateral ceasefire issued by the Sudanese government on 18 June 2016 tensions escalated. In March 2017, SPLM/A-N deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu publicly released a resignation letter. Abdelaziz al-Hilu accused Agar of not fully representing the entire SPLM/A-N movement in the peace process led by the AU, particularly with regard to the issue of self-determination of the Nuba Mountains. Al-Hilu’s letter essentially forced the members of the SPLM/A-N to choose between himself and chairman Malik Agar of the Ingessana tribe. The Nuba Mountains Liberation Council (NMLC) subsequently passed resolutions that removed Arman as the SPLM/A-N’s lead negotiator with African Union High-Level Implementation Panel (AUHIP), as well as put the NMLC in power of both South Kordofan and Blue Nile. Moreover, many senior non-Ingessana leaders began to publicly voice support for al-Hilu and the NMLC. In April 2017, almost all of the non-Ingessana Blue Nile Liberation Council (BNLC) members declared their support for the NMLC decision to dismiss Arman as the SPLM/A-N AUHIP lead negotiator. Accordingly, although the deputy chairman Abdelaziz al-Hilu broke away from the rebel group led by chairman Malik Agar, the UCDP codes the SPLM/A-N led by Malik Agar (SPLM/A-N-MA) as the splinter faction because he was endorsed by the NMLC and most of the BNLC.  Preparations for official negotiations between the SPLM/A-North and the Sudanese government continued in spite of this split. SPLM/A-North representatives met with mediators from the AUHIP in Addis Ababa in late August 2017. In late September 2017, Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) special envoy for Sudan, Lesane Johannes, discussed details for the resumption of formal peace talks between the SPLM-North and the government with Sudanese Presidential adviser Ibrahim Mahmoud. However, these pre-negotiations did not lead to formal negotiations between the SPLM-North and the Government of Sudan were held in 2017."

"The ARCSS included a political power-sharing provision. To this purpose, Machar returned to Juba in April 2016. However, problems with the implementation of the ARCSS were already apparent prior to Machar’s return. Kiir had cast aside the power-sharing formula of the ARCSS in October 2015 through creating 28 states instead of ten states. In addition, in violation to the agreement, Chief of Staff Paul Malong had secretly brought a Dinka militia to Juba. With tensions increasing, fighting between the conflict parties eventually resumed in July 2016. This effectively suspended the peace process. Following the clashes, President Kiir issued a decree on an immediate ceasefire in the country on 11 July 2016. Yet, fighting continued. Riek Machar subsequently fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo while under attack of ground forces and helicopter gunships. Taban Deng Gai sought the support of some disgruntled SPLM/A-IO generals, after which Kiir appointed Taban Deng Gai as the vice president, replacing Machar. Riek Machar was later put under house arrest in South Africa. However, most of the SPLM/A-IO remained loyal to Machar. JMEC chairman Festus Mogae reported in October 2016 that “near-daily violations” of the ceasefire by both parties, warning that these could 'trigger an uncontrolled escalation of violence.'"

agreement name: Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM
notes_1: "Building on the Arusha Agreement that had been concluded in January 2015, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni mediated a round of negotiations between the three factions with the SPLM/A in July 2017. This round of negotiations involving the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees led to the signing of the Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM on 27 July 2017. This agreement established a working group to revitalize and operationalize the implementation of the Arusha Agreement, trying to reunify the SPLM/A. In addition. IGAD tried “revitalize” the peace process from mid-2017 onwards.  The IGAD leaders endorsed a plan to kick-start the peace process at the 31st Extra-ordinary Summit of IGAD Assembly of Heads of State on 12 June 2017. IGAD announced on 1  October 2017 that it would resume the formal peace process to bring peace to South Sudan."

agreement name: Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)
notes_1: "In addition, Egypt and Uganda had mediated a round of negotiations in Cairo in November 2017 aimed at reunifying the SPLM/A. On 16 November 2017, representatives of the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees signed the Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)."

agreement name: Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement
notes_1: "'The (SSOMA) is informing its entire membership. supporters, South Sudanese at large and the International Community that it has together with the Government (...) signed Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement COHA (of) December 2017 under the auspices of the Community of Sant’Egidio,' said the alliance on Friday." Other groups had previously signed this cessation of hostilities agreement in December 2017.
"As part of the Joint Demarcation Committee, the AU mediated between representatives of Sudan and South Sudan between 10 and 13 September 2018. However, no progress was made."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "A round of negotiations between the Sudanese government and JEM in February 2018, mediated by Qatar, led to the signing of a ceasefire on 11 February 2018. The ceasefire was signed by Mohamed Bashir Ahmed of the JEM-Military Command in Qatar.Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019."

"On 30 January 2018, the SPLM/A-North announced an extension of the unilateral ceasefire at South Kordofan and Blue Nile areas for four month starting on 1 February 2018. Pre-negotiations resumed in Addis Ababa on 3 February 2018, but the talks broke down on 4 February because the government refused the SPLM/A-North’s demand for greater autonomy."

"On 30 January 2018, the SPLM/A-North announced an extension of the unilateral ceasefire at South Kordofan and Blue Nile areas for four month starting on 1 February 2018. Pre-negotiations resumed in Addis Ababa on 3 February 2018, but the talks broke down on 4 February because the government refused the SPLM/A-North’s demand for greater autonomy."

"Another round of exploratory peace talks was held between the Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-North in Addis Ababa and Johannesburg between 19 and 30 October 2018, but both sides continued to disagree on the terms of resuming official peace talks. Nevertheless, on 3 November 2018, the Sudanese government agreed to the proposal of SPLM/A-North to appoint South Sudanese President Salva Kiir as the chief mediator of future negotiations."

"Several rounds of informal negotiations were held in Berlin throughout 2018. The German Foreign Ministry and the Berghof Foundation acted as mediators at these exploratory talks. These negotiations were aimed at initiating formal negotiations between the SRF alliance and the Sudanese government. Representatives of the JEM and the SLM/A-MM, representing the SRF, and the Sudanese government conducted pre-negotiations in Berlin on 16 and 17 April 2018. The Joint Special Representative for Darfur and representatives of Norway, the UK, and the US also particpated in these pre-negotiations."

"On 2 January 2018, the Troika – comprising of the US, the UK, and Norway – called on the conflict parties to end their military operations and threatened to impose sanctions on those who would not comply with this call. The IGAD-led mediation process continued in 2018. The second round of the IGAD revitalization forum was held in Addis Ababa between 5 and 16 February 2018, but no agreement was reached."

"A round of proximity talks  was held between the conflict parties in Addis Ababa on 11 and 12 May 2018.  This round of indirect talks was followed by the resumption of the revitalization forum in Addis Ababa from 17 to 23 May 2018. The South Sudan Council of Churches supported this IGAD-led round of negotiations through facilitating dialogue sessions to bridge their differences on the outstanding governance and security issues identified as critical to revitalize the Agreement.  The conflict parties recommitted to the implementation of the cessation of hostilities agreement, but little substantial progress was made. Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially led the effort the revitalize the peace process following his election in April 2018."

Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially led the effort the revitalize the peace process following his election in April 2018."

"A round of proximity talks  was held between the conflict parties in Addis Ababa on 11 and 12 May 2018.  This round of indirect talks was followed by the resumption of the revitalization forum in Addis Ababa from 17 to 23 May 2018. The South Sudan Council of Churches supported this IGAD-led round of negotiations through facilitating dialogue sessions to bridge their differences on the outstanding governance and security issues identified as critical to revitalize the Agreement. "The conflict parties engaged in shuttle negotiations in Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 June 2018, but Abiy Ahmed mediated a face-to-face meeting between President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar on the final day of this round of negotiations. This was the first meeting of Kiir and Machar since the resumption of hostilities in July 2016. The following day, on 21 June 2018, the IGAD Assembly of Heads of State and Government mandated Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir to mediate the negotiations. President al-Bashir was supported by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni."

agreement name: Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan
notes_1: "Face-to-face talks between President Kiir and Machar resumed in Khartoum on 25 June and concluded with the Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan on 27 June. This agreement was also signed by the representatives of the South Sudan Opposition Alliance, the “Former Detainees”, and the other political parties. In the Declaration, the signatories announced a permanent ceasefire, set objectives for transitional security arrangements and signatories to reach an agreement on the IGAD revised bridging proposal, improve infrastructure and basic services in South Sudan and restore oil fields in Unity. The agreement also stipulates a comprehensive ceasefire. This agreement commits the conflict parties to a permanent ceasefire and to finalize a deal on the pending issues in the governance chapter of the 2015 peace agreement. stipulated a “revised bridging proposal” that listed the details of a pre-transitional period. The agreement also includes provisions with regard to the oil, elections, and reconstruction. The agreement thus was meant to pave the way for the formation of an inclusive transitional cabinet. The agreement also called upon the AU and IGAD to deploy protection forces and ceasefire monitors to observe the ceasefire implementation. In addition, the conflict parties agreed to open the humanitarian corridors, release detainees, withdraw troops and militarily disengage."

agreement name: Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements
notes_1: "On 6 July 2018,  following a round of negotiations mediated by  Sudan and Uganda in Khartoum, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements, which included additional provisions on the ceasefire and the Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR) process."

agreement name: Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance
notes_1: "The conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance on 5 August 2018. This agreement supplemented and/or amended previously agreed provisions on political power-sharing through specifying who will hold the key government ministries and positions."

"Building on progress made through the signing of the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance, another round of negotiations was held in Khartoum  between  13 and 19 August 2018. These talks mainly focused on the status and incorporation of the documents agreed upon in Addis Ababa and in Khartoum in the preceding months. On 18 August 2018, the mediators circulated a draft revitalized text of the peace agreement to the parties for comment before adjourning for the Eid holidays."

agreement name: Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan
notes_1: "The conflict parties signed a final agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS). While the Troika had been involved in most of the IGAD-led negotiations in 2018, they were excluded from the final rounds of negotiations. The Troika therefore refused to co-sign the R-ARCSS. The agreement outlined a revised comprehensive framework for the transition from conflict. The agreement stipulated the reinstatement of Machar as First Vice President and the establishment of a transitional government in May 2019. In addition, in line with the agreement, Kiir ordered the release of all prisoners of war and detainees in September 2018. Kiir and Machar jointly attended peace celebrations in the capital Juba on October 31 2018, together with the presidents of Sudan, Uganda, Somalia, and Ethiopia, as well as Egypt’s prime minister. Nevertheless, fighting between government forces and the SPLM/A-IO continued throughout the year, though at a lower intensity."

notes_1: "The conflict parties signed a final agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS). While the Troika had been involved in most of the IGAD-led negotiations in 2018, they were excluded from the final rounds of negotiations. The Troika therefore refused to co-sign the R-ARCSS. The agreement outlined a revised comprehensive framework for the transition from conflict. The agreement stipulated the reinstatement of Machar as First Vice President and the establishment of a transitional government in May 2019. In addition, in line with the agreement, Kiir ordered the release of all prisoners of war and detainees in September 2018. Kiir and Machar jointly attended peace celebrations in the capital Juba on October 31 2018, together with the presidents of Sudan, Uganda, Somalia, and Ethiopia, as well as Egypt’s prime minister. Nevertheless, fighting between government forces and the SPLM/A-IO continued throughout the year, though at a lower intensity."

"Throughout 2019, the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNSIFA) mediated meetings with officials from Sudan and South Sudan to promote peace in Abyei."

"As the uprising unfolded, al-Bashir lost his few remaining allies. None of his foreign sponsors came to the rescue. On December 24, when Gen. Mohammed Hamdan Daglo, known as Hemedti, the head of the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, came out supporting demonstrators’ demands, it became clear that the loyalty of the military and security apparatus was shaky. In mid-February, as demonstrations continued unabated, the head of the security service Salah Gosh and the UAE reportedly offered al-Bashir an exit plan, which he refused.  The Emiratis began to reach out to opposition groups; so did Gosh, who visited prominent leaders in prison.[11]"
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishement of ties with specific groups in the conflict.

notes_1: "On 7 April 2019, a day after revolutionary demonstrators began a sit-in in front of the military’s headquarters, Gen. Jalal al-Dine el-Sheikh, the deputy head of the security service, headed a delegation of military and intelligence officials to Cairo, where he sought the support of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the UAE for a coup against al-Bashir. The three countries then reportedly reached out to Abdelfattah al-Burhan, a military general who had coordinated the Sudanese military’s operations in the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen, and Hemedti, who had also deployed there as head of the RSF. Egypt offered Bashir exile in Saudi Arabia. Again, he refused. A few days later, on 11 April, leaders of the military and security apparatus, including al-Burhan and Hemedti, overthrew him, installing a Transitional Military Council (TMC) to rule the country.[12] This coup gave an opportunity for the UAE, Saudi Arabia and Egypt to finally bring Sudan into their axis. They threw their weight behind the TMC, and in particular Hemedti, who had already acquired considerable financial resources in the last year of al-Bashir’s rule thanks to the deployment of the RSF in Yemen and his exports of Sudan’s gold to Dubai.[13]Within ten days, the UAE and Saudi Arabia had promised $3 billion of direct aid to the new regime. While revolutionaries continued their sit-in, demanding radical political change, Egypt lobbied the African Union to discourage a suspension of Sudan’s membership.[14]"
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishement of ties with specific groups in the conflict.

notes_1: "On 3 June, after a visit by Hemedti to Riyadh, Cairo and Abu Dhabi (Crisis Group 2019:12), RSF and police forces cracked down on the Khartoum sit-in, killing more than 130 people and sparking indignation in Sudan and abroad. The event prompted the US and the UK, after weeks of passivity, to pressure the UAE and Saudi Arabia.[25] Emirati and Saudi officials, reportedly concerned that Hemedti had gone too far and was precipitating instability, used their influence on the TMC to push for a deal with the opposition.[26] They began to publicly call for “dialogue”, and to work behind the scenes alongside the UK and the US to broker a deal.[27]"
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishement of ties with specific groups in the conflict.
note_3: "After the signing of the constitutional declaration, which laid out a roadmap to a constitutional conference and elections, the UAE and Saudi Arabia provided support to the new government, funneling $200 million monthly in cash and commodity subsidies to the government for the second half of 2019.[31] In line with this new alignment, the Sudanese government, though desperate for cash, turned down an offer to send a delegation to Qatar in exchange for $1 billion in financing.[32]"

note_3:
"After the signing of the constitutional declaration, which laid out a roadmap to a constitutional conference and elections, the UAE and Saudi Arabia provided support to the new government, funneling $200 million monthly in cash and commodity subsidies to the government for the second half of 2019.[31] In line with this new alignment, the Sudanese government, though desperate for cash, turned down an offer to send a delegation to Qatar in exchange for $1 billion in financing.[32]

Domestically, the new alliance between the FFC and the former TMC members dramatically reconfigured the Sudanese state at the expense of the NCP, in line with Gulf backers’ hostility towards the Muslim Brotherhood. Top NCP representatives faced jail and their assets were seized. Al-Burhan, who had served as the military’ coordinator with the ruling party,[33] pivoted to please his patrons and purged many who were too clearly identified as Islamists from the military and the security service.[34] UAE influence came to pervade the Sudanese political scene. Hemedti, whom a diplomat described as “the agent and the proxy of the Emirates”,[35] consolidated his position as a central player thanks to his ability to buy off potential dissenters and competitors.[36] Sudan Call’s leaders, such as Yasir Arman and Sadig al-Mahdi, the leader of the Umma Party, continued to express public support to the participation of the military in the transition and worked to marginalize leftist groups not affiliated to the UAE.[37]"

agreement name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation
notes_1: "First, the Emiratis have sponsored a peace process that puts the generals front and center. The constitutional declaration was unclear about who, in the new power configuration, should be in charge of negotiations with armed groups from Darfur, Southern Kordofan and Blue Nile – a priority for the transition.[38] The generals seized on this ambiguity. Hemedti and Gen. Shamseddine al-Kabbashi, another former member of the TMC, wrested the process from the cabinet, heading government delegations in Juba, where the negotiations have been taking place with financial backing from the UAE. Abu Dhabi has used its influence with armed groups to push for a deal that would put the generals in the positions of peacemakers, though internal divisions between the RSF and SAF and the FFC’s belated effort to join the talks have been stumbling blocks (by the spring of 2020, Hemedti was happy to leave the file to al-Kabbashi).[39]"
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UAE's sponsorship and funding of the initiative.

agreement name: Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation
notes_1: "Following a massive popular uprising, President Omar al-Bashir was ousted from power in April 2019. The transitional government that was put in place continued to negotiate with the SRF. Negotiations in Juba in September 2019 led to the signing of the Juba Declaration for Confidence Building Procedures and the Preparation for Negotiation on 11 September 2019."

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: "A second round of negotiations in Juba between 14 and 21 October led to the signing of a political declaration between the transitional Government and SRF."

"The R-ARCSS stipulated that Salva Kiir and Riek Machar had to form a unity government by May 2019. On 2 May 2019, IGAD mediated a round of negotiations in Addis Ababa where the conflict parties and the IGAD mediation team agreed to extend the deadline to 12 November 2019. The conflict parties indicated that this extension was needed to complete the necessary transitional security arrangements, including protection for senior government officials, to form the transitional Government. However, follow-up mediation was also needed to address more substantial issues. The International Crisis Group reported on the need for follow-up mediation on the R-ARCSS, stating that “The accord, brokered by Sudan’s Omar al-Bashir and Uganda’s Yoweri Museveni, is not a finished product and requires revision” and that “Additional political deals are necessary on two crucial matters – unifying a national army and resolving bitter disagreements over local boundaries and administration inside South Sudan. Absent such deals, the Kiir-Machar truce may fail its first major test in May 2019, when the two South Sudanese leaders are scheduled to form a unity government.” On 18 October, in a communiqué, the Peace and Security Council of the AU called for the parties’ adherence to the deadline of 12 November. During its visit to South Sudan on 20 October 2019, the UN Security Council also called for adhering to the deadline, but also stressed the need to address outstanding issues. While the Government of South Sudan intended to form the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity on 12 November, the SPLM/A-IO called for an extension."

"President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019."

"President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to involvement in the negotiation short of mediation.

The talks led to the endorsement of the plan to extend the deadline with 100 days in order to facilitate the resolution of the outstanding issues."

agreement name: Framework Agreement for Peace in Darfur
notes_1: South Sudanese chief mediator Tut Gatluak mediated talks between the head of the Sudanese government's mediation team, Shams al-Din Kabbashi, and representatives from the four armed groups: JEM, SLM led by Minni Minnawi, Sudan Liberation Movement Tansitional Council, and the Sudan Liberation Forces Alliance. These talks culminated in the Framework Agreement for Peace in Darfur on 28 December 2019. The Sudan Liberation Movement boycotted the process.

agreement name: Framework Agreement for Peace in Darfur
notes_1: UNAMID supported the South Sudanese efforts to mediate the Framework Agreement for Peace in Darfur.

"Last November Cirilo was in Rome for meetings with Sant' Edigio officials on ways to reach a negotiated settlement for the armed conflict in the country.

At the end of his two-day discussions, he issued a statement on 20 November 2019 calling on Sant’ Egidio to engage with his alliance, the government and other signatories of the revitalized peace agreement from one side and the regional and international partners on the other side to "make this dialogue process a success".

In a meeting held in Rome during his visit to Rome in March 2019, President Salva Kiir encouraged Sant’ Egidio to continue its efforts for an inclusive peace in his country.

Last November, President Salva Kiir and his main peace partner Riek Machar agreed to delay the formation of the transitional national unity government until next February."
The Troika released a statement pressuring parties in South Sudan to deliver on their commitments to the R-ARCSS and form a national unity government.
The Troika released a statement pressuring parties in South Sudan to deliver on their commitments to the R-ARCSS and form a national unity government.

"Khartoum, 8 January 2020. A joint Government and UN delegation just returned from a two day visit to El Geneina, West Darfur, 5-6 January, having assessed the situation to provide immediate humanitarian assistance to the needs of the most vulnerable, particularly women, children and the people with disabilities. The delegation included the Humanitarian Aid Commission (HAC), the Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Labour and Social Development, together with the Resident and Humanitarian Coordinator and the Representatives of WFP and UNICEF. The delegation met with affected people, West Darfur State Governor (Wali), the West Darfur HAC Commissioner, the Deputy Sultan, and Arab leaders."

"The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is distributing Essential Household Items (EHIs) to those affected by the violence which began on December 28, 2019, around El Geneina, West Darfur, causing several deaths, injuries, and displacement of thousands of persons within the area and into Chad....The ICRC is a neutral and independent humanitarian organization and continues to respond to humanitarian needs in Sudan. Last year, it delivered safe drinking water to 326,407 persons and vaccinated over 325'810 animals in Darfur, South Kordofan and the Blue Nile; provided seeds and farming tools to 138,000 persons in North and Central Darfur and supported 7 health facilities in Khartoum to care for those injured during the Sudanese protests. In the past, and based on its role as a neutral intermediary, the ICRC variously facilitated the return of combatants in the power of parties during the Sudanese conflict back to their respective locations. The on-going humanitarian response in West Darfur is consistent with the mandate of the ICRC to alleviate the suffering of those affected by armed conflict and violence and provide them with succor."

On 9 January 2020 "[t]he UN World Food Programme (WFP) Executive Director, David Beasley, accompanied by the Prime Minister of Sudan, Abdalla Hamdok, today visited Kauda in the Nuba Mountains region of South Kordofan, marking a new milestone in the gradual expansion of humanitarian access to contested areas of Sudan. Also taking part in the confidence-building mission were five Sudanese government ministers, three Khartoum-based diplomats and United Nations officials."

The delegation was received by Sudan People Liberation Movement North (SPLM-N) leader, Abdulaziz Al-Hilu, and WFP employees from South Sudan. The Executive Director used his good offices to facilitate the first visit of Sudanese officials to non-government-controlled areas in South Kordofan in more than nine years.

"On 9 January, the Prime Minister of Sudan, Dr. Abdalla Hamdok, the Minister of Labour and Social Development, the Minister of Health, the Executive Director of the World Food Programme, the United Nations Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator (RC/HC) in Sudan, Gwi-Yeop Son and representatives of UN agencies and diplomatic missions in Sudan visited Kauda in the Nuba Mountains area of South Kordofan State.

This is the first joint Government and United Nations mission to the area since fighting broke out in 2011. The delegation was received by Abdelaziz al-Hilu, leader of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement – North (SPLM-N) al-Hilu faction."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UN's support for the government's and rebels humanitarian efforts in the South Kordofan and Blue Nile regions.

notes_1:
"January 11, 2019 (JUBA) - South Sudanese government and three opposition holdout groups have launched discussions on peace in the country organized by the Roman Catholic Sant’ Egidio peace group.

The five-day meeting discusses ways to bring the South Sudan Opposition Alliance led by Thomas Cirilo, South Sudan United Front/ Army, under the leadership of General Paul Malong Awan Anei; and Pagan Amum, the leader of Former Detainees group.

The government’s delegation is led by the former Foreign Minister Barnaba Marial Benjamin who is flanked by the cabinet minister Elia Lomuoro and the head of the National Security Service Akol Koor Kuc.

Several sources confirmed to Sudan Tribune the meeting which started on Friday and is expected to end on Tuesday 14 January."

"Zalingei, 14 January 2020 - On 13 January, UNAMID Joint Special Representative/Joint Chief Mediator (JSR/JCM), Jeremiah Mamabolo visited the deserted Krinding camp for internally displaced persons (IDPs) in El Geneina town in West Darfur State, to assess the extent of damage during the recent intercommunal clashes that resulted in a number of fatalities and injuries as well as mass displacement amongst the civilian population in the area."

"The fifth training program of the training project launched by Turkish Cooperation and Coordination Agency (TİKA) for 12 OIC member states in cooperation with the Statistical, Economic and Social Research and Training Center for Islamic Countries (SESRIC) and the Ministries of Health of Turkey and Sudan was organized in the Gambia."

"(London, 17 January 2020): International donors today affirmed the importance of scaling up their humanitarian assistance to Sudan in 2020 and of frontloading resources early in the year.

At a High-Level Roundtable in London co-hosted by the UK, Sweden, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and with participation of the Sudanese Government, 19 international donors also reviewed plans for life-saving and life-sustaining relief to people in need and emphasized the importance of providing funding effectively including through multiyear and flexible support. Sudan also received assurances from the United Nations and NGOs to step up response to address the country's urgent humanitarian needs."

"(19 January, London) - Saudi Arabia, the biggest aid provider to Sudan, has pledge continued commitment to the beleaguered state. The pledge was made a high-level roundtable on Humanitarian Aid in Sudan co-hosted by the UK, Sweden and the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in London."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to Saudi Arabia's reiteration of its support to Sudan.

notes_1: "14 January 2020 – The World Health Organization (WHO) and health partners are responding to the health needs of people affected by recent conflict in El Geneina, West Darfur, Sudan. To date, WHO has delivered medicines and medical supplies for more than 120 200 people, including those in need of trauma or surgical care. Other supplies delivered by health partners include medicines for diarrhoeal diseases, childhood illnesses, and obstetric deliveries."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the WHO's supply of medical equipment to West Darfur.

notes_1: "January 19th, 2020 ― Doha: Today, a Qatar Emiri Air Force (QEAF) aircraft arrived in Khartoum to deliver the first shipment of medical aid donated by the State of Qatar to the Republic of Sudan. Under a humanitarian intervention conducted by Qatar Red Crescent Society (QRCS), the aircraft landed at Khartoum International Airport with diverse medical supplies aboard. It is the first of three batches of medical aid, totaling 70 tons, donated for Sudan’s Federal Ministry of Health (FMOH). The remaining batches are to arrive over the coming few days."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the supply of medical equipment to Sudan.
note_3: "January 22nd, 2020 ― Doha: The delegation of Qatar Emiri Air Force (QEAF) is supervising the handover and distribution of the Qatari medical aid of 70 tons, intended to support the health sector in Sudan. They also held several meetings with various partners."

notes_1:
"AECID activa el convenio de emergencias que mantiene con Acción contra el Hambre para una intervención de urgencia por un importe de 51.000 euros

Las intensas lluvias acaecidas en los meses de agosto y septiembre en Sudán causaron graves inundaciones en el país, afectando a más de 426.000 personas, casi el doble en comparación con las inundaciones de 2018. Los estados más afectados por las inundaciones fueron White Nile, Kassala, Khartoum, Kordofan Oeste y Darfur Norte, según datos de la Oficina de Coordinación Humanitaria de las Naciones Unidas (OCHA).

Para dar respuesta a las necesidades humanitarias causadas por esta situación, la Agencia Española de Cooperación Internacional para el Desarrollo (AECID) ha activado recientemente el convenio de emergencias que mantiene con la ONG Acción contra el Hambre para llevar a cabo una intervención en la localidad de Um Rimta, estado de White Nile, por un importe de 51.000 euros. El objetivo es contribuir a la recuperación de las poblaciones afectadas por las inundaciones, así como facilitar la identificación y tratamiento de enfermedades comunes y malnutrición de menores de 5 años y la consulta prenatal y postnatal de mujeres lactantes y embarazadas."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to AECID's supply of medical suplpies to Sudan.

notes_1: "January 22, 2020 (Khartoum) – The Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) today renewed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with respect to the ICRC's support to the SAF for the teaching and integration of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) within their Armed Forces. The document was first signed in 2008. It has been renewed regularly ever since, most recently in 2015."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the ICRC teaching the laws of war in accordance with international humanitarian law and the renewal of an MoU.

agreement name: Framework peace agreement with Agar
notes_1:
"January 24, 2020 (JUBA) - The Sudanese government and the SPLM-N led by Malik Agar signed a framework peace agreement in Juba on Friday, ahead of comprehensive peace agreement with armed groups before mid-February.

The purpose of the framework agreement with Agar group which is part of the Sudanese Revolutionary Front (SRF)is to end the nearly 9-year armed conflict in the Blue Nile and South Kordofan states.

The dispositions of the signed deal included the right to legislate in the two areas, land ownership, power and wealth sharing and principles of security arrangements.

It is expected to be followed by a comprehensive peace agreement between the government and the SRF groups in Darfur and eastern Sudan before 14 February, once the other tracks complete framework agreements.

The signing ceremony took place at the presidential palace in Juba, in the presence of President Salva Kiir, a number of Sudanese government officials and the leaders of the Revolutionary Front."

"In accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2495 (2019), which mandated UNAMID to support the peace process, the Mission is providing logistical support to the Peace Commission, Transitional

Government of Sudan, and Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF) Darfur Track members to enable them to travel to different Darfur states to organize two major consultative conferences for IDPs (Internally Displaced Persons), native administration and civil society to facilitate their participation in peace talks currently underway in Juba, South Sudan.

The two conferences will be held in El Fasher, north Darfur before the end of January 2020 after conclusion of consultations with various stakeholders by the Joint Field Committee (JFC) comprising the National Peace Commission, the Transitional Government of Sudan and the SRF Darfur Tracks."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to UNAMID's hosting of cultative meetings and provision of logistical support.
note_5: "El Fasher, north Darfur; The Joint Field Committee (JFC), consisting of the Transitional Government of Sudan (TGoS) and the Sudan Revolutionary Front (SRF)- Darfur Track in partnership with UNAMID, organized two consultative conferences to identify representatives of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), civil society and Native Administration drawn from all five Darfur States, to participate in the peace talks in Juba, South Sudan. In accordance with the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2495 (2019), UNAMID is providing logistical support to the Sudan Peace Commission, TGoS, and SRF -Darfur Track, to organize these two major consultative conferences."

notes_1: "Zalingei, 26 January 2020— In the aftermath of the recent looting incidents of UN assets in West, South and more recently, North Darfur, UNAMID’s Joint Special Representative/Joint Chief Mediator, Jeremiah Mamabolo met with Government of Sudan officials, and agreed to immediately reactivate a joint security mechanism that will allow for speedy security related consultations and decisions."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishment of security mechanisms.

notes_1:
"The United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) in Sudan hosted a three-day event on post-harvest losses, to explore ways of reducing food losses through approaches such as hermetic storage bags that were showcased at the event.

The event held from 27 to 29 January linked various actors in the food value chain, including international manufacturers, national distributors and marketing companies along with government representatives from the Ministry of Agriculture – a key supporter and co-host of the event."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UN's WFP hosting a reound-table consultative event.

notes_1: "Khartoum, Sudan - The international community must immediately boost its support to Sudan to accelerate its transition to civilian rule, allowing it to sustain peace and accelerate much-need development, said Achim Steiner, the Head of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) as he concluded his three-day visit to Sudan -- the first ever by a UNDP Administrator."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UNDP Administrator's tour of Sudan.

notes_1:
"Advancing mediation and conflict prevention capacities of Sudanese women to ensure effective and enhanced mediation interventions.

ACCORD in partnership with the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) Mediation Support Unit (MSU) held a three-day Training of Trainers for Sudanese women from the Blue Nile and Nuba Mountains. The training was held from the 3-5 February 2020 in Juba, South Sudan."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to training provided by the South African entity ACCORD for Sudanese women in mediation and conflict resolution supported by IGAD.

notes_1:
"H.E. Finance Minister Dr. Ibrahim al-Badawi and H.E. the State Secretary for Foreign Affairs of Sweden Amb. Robert Rydberg made opening remarks at the sixth meeting of the Friends of Sudan meeting in Stockholm on 18 February. Representatives of the Government of Sudan presented further information about the economic reform process and provided an update of the peace process. Sweden’s Deputy Director-General and Head of Africa Department Irina Schoulgin Nyoni chaired the meeting.

Representatives from the African Development Bank, Canada, Egypt, European Union, Ethiopia, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Kuwait, The Netherlands, Norway, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United Nations, United States, the World Bank and the Government of Sudan participated in the meeting. All participants engaged in broad discussions on how the international community can best support Sudan’s Transitional Government in its efforts to achieve peace and promote economic recovery and development."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to broad discussions about how the international community can support Sudan in general terms.

Representatives from the African Development Bank, Canada, Egypt, European Union, Ethiopia, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Kuwait, The Netherlands, Norway, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Sweden, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United Nations, United States, the World Bank and the Government of Sudan participated in the meeting. All participants engaged in broad discussions on how the international community can best support Sudan’s Transitional Government in its efforts to achieve peace and promote economic recovery and development."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to broad discussions about how the international community can support Sudan in general terms.
